Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the number of people who allegedly voted illegally, stating that there were "millions" of illegal votes.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient evidence or support to substantiate the assertion that millions of people voted illegally.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that deducting the alleged illegal votes would result in the speaker winning the popular vote, without providing any evidence or logical reasoning to support this assumption.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the author of the study, upon which the claim is based, does not support or validate the claim.
Understate: The claim understates the legitimacy of the popular vote, as it implies that the only reason the speaker did not win the popular vote is due to alleged illegal votes.
Exist alternative explanation: There is an alternative explanation to the claim, which is that the speaker did not win the popular vote due to other factors beyond alleged illegal voting.
